body:
I have a sneaking suspicion this comes in part from queued component registration . See [here](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/blob/3dc6a07d27e132ea81985809d0636da230cde320/crates/bevy_ecs/src/component.rs#L2439). This explains the 11x regression in `get_not_found`. We can fix it pretty easy with `Components::get_valid_id` instead of `get_id`, which now has atomic locking in it. 

I don't think this fully explains the regression for `get`/`get_mut`, but I wouldn't be surprised if they are related. 

First step is definitely benchmarks. I'd be curious if this went away with `Query` instead of `EntityWorldMut` and if we flush queued component registration before running the benches. If the flush helps, that would explain why the regression was not felt anywhere: the flush is called once per frame already.

issue.title: Fix regression on the get/get_mut/get_not_found

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

- Partial fix #19504
- As more features were added to Bevy ECS, certain core hot-path function calls exceeded LLVM's automatic inlining threshold, leading to significant performance regressions in some cases.



## Solution

- inline more functions.


## Performance
This brought nearly 3x improvement in Windows bench (using Sander's testing code)

body:
> > if we flush queued component registration before running the benches
> 
> [@ElliottjPierce](https://github.com/ElliottjPierce) how do I do that?

Just call `flush` after the component is in the registration queue. Probably don't even need this tbh; just trying to eliminate things.

> EDIT: note that the code repeats the same benchmark many times, so if component registration only happens on the first call it likely only still has a small impact (but would still be good to eliminate).

Yes, I'm thinking in particularly about the 11x regression in `get_not_found`, which has a component that is not registered. When checking for unregistered components, it locks. If the component, `C2` in the bench, were registered head of time or we changed the `get_id` like I mentioned, this wouldn't be an issue. But right now, the bench locks when `.get::<C2>()` etc are called.

I suspect that between this and #19505, these regressions will be fixed.
That does actually seem to make a difference. If I call `world.spawn(C2(...))` ahead of time the benchmark improves significantly. I'll share updated numbers after the fixes have landed.

> [@ElliottjPierce](https://github.com/ElliottjPierce)
> 
> > Just call flush after the component is in the registration queue. Probably don't even need this tbh; just trying to eliminate things.
> 
> How do I do that? How do I put a component in the registration queue? What do I call flush on? The world?

See #18173. I think actually doing it is irrelevant to the benches. It's its existence that causes there to be the atomic locking sometimes. If you do want to test it, `World::flush` and `World::components_queue` are what you want, but I don't think it's important here.

issue.title: Only get valid component ids

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

- #19504 showed a 11x regression in getting component values for unregistered components. This pr should fix that and improve others a little too.
- This is some cleanup work from #18173 .

## Solution

- Whenever we expect a component value to exist, we only care about fully registered components, not queued to be registered components since, for the value to exist, it must be registered.
- So we can use the faster `get_valid_*` instead of `get_*` in a lot of places.
- Also found a bug where `valid_*` did not forward to `get_valid_*` properly. That's fixed.

## Testing

CI

body: Merging the two linked PRs: we should re-bench once those are in. If that's resolved, I'd like to do a point release ASAP.
